sections.title: What is Shogi?
sections.content:
Shogi (将棋, shōgi) - literally 'general's chess' - is a traditional Japanese board game for two players, similar to chess but with unique mechanics that make it deeply strategic.

**The Board**: 9×9 grid (81 squares) - smaller than Go, larger than chess
**The Goal**: Checkmate the opponent's King (玉将/王将)
**Key Difference**: **Piece drops** - captured pieces can be returned to the board as your own!

**Why Shogi is Special**:
• No draws - games must have a winner
• Pieces can be reused after capture
• All pieces promote when reaching enemy territory
• Deeper than chess - estimated 10^226 possible positions!

**Cultural Significance**: 
Shogi has been played in Japan for over 500 years. Professional players are celebrities, and top players like Yoshiharu Habu and Sota Fujii are national treasures.

sections.title: The Pieces (駒, koma)
sections.content:
**Starting Forces** (20 pieces each):

**Major Pieces**:
• **King** (玉将/王将, ōshō/gyokushō) - Moves one square in any direction
• **Rook** (飛車, hisha) - Moves any distance horizontally or vertically
  → Promotes to **Dragon King** (竜王, ryūō) - Rook + diagonal moves
• **Bishop** (角行, kakugyō) - Moves any distance diagonally
  → Promotes to **Dragon Horse** (竜馬, ryūma) - Bishop + orthogonal moves

**Gold & Silver**:
• **Gold General** (金将, kinshō) - Moves one square except diagonal backward
  → Does NOT promote (already powerful!)
• **Silver General** (銀将, ginshō) - Moves one square forward or diagonally
  → Promotes to **Promoted Silver** (成銀, narigin) - moves like Gold

**Minor Pieces**:
• **Knight** (桂馬, keima) - Jumps two squares forward, one square sideways (L-shape, but only forward!)
  → Promotes to **Promoted Knight** (成桂, narikei) - moves like Gold
• **Lance** (香車, kyōsha) - Moves any distance forward only
  → Promotes to **Promoted Lance** (成香, narikyō) - moves like Gold
• **Pawn** (歩兵, fuhyō) - Moves and captures one square forward
  → Promotes to **Tokin** (と金, tokin) - moves like Gold

**Key Rule**: **Two Pawns** (二歩, nifu) - You CANNOT have two unpromoted pawns in the same file!

sections.title: Special Rules - The Drop Mechanic
sections.content:
**THE PIECE DROP** (駒を打つ, koma o utsu):
This is what makes Shogi UNIQUE!

**How It Works**:
1. Capture opponent's piece → It becomes yours
2. On your turn, instead of moving, you can **drop** a captured piece anywhere on the board
3. Dropped pieces can be used immediately!

**Drop Restrictions**:
• Pawns: Cannot drop for immediate checkmate (打ち歩詰め, uchifuzume)
• Pawns: Cannot drop if you already have an unpromoted pawn in that file
• Pieces cannot drop on squares where they cannot move (e.g., knight on last two ranks)
• Pieces drop in unpromoted form

**Why This Matters**:
• Games rarely simplify - captured pieces come back!
• Material advantage is temporary
• Positional understanding becomes crucial
• Endgames are incredibly complex

**Strategic Implications**:
"In chess, a piece exchange simplifies the position. In Shogi, it complicates it!" - Professional saying

This mechanic means Shogi games stay dynamic from opening to endgame. There's no "simplifying into a draw" - you must fight to the end!

sections.title: Promotion Zone (成り, nari)
sections.content:
**The Promotion Zone**: Last 3 ranks of the board (opponent's territory)

**Promotion Rules**:
• When a piece enters, moves within, or leaves the promotion zone, you can promote it
• Promotion is optional (except when the piece cannot move further unpromoted)
• King and Gold cannot promote
• Promoted pieces have their name written in red on the reverse side

**Strategic Considerations**:

**When to Promote**:
✅ Pawns → Always promote to Tokin (Gold movement is much better!)
✅ Lance/Knight → Usually promote (Gold movement more flexible)
✅ Silver → Often promote (Gold is more stable)
✅ Bishop/Rook → Depends on position!

**When NOT to Promote**:
❌ Rook/Bishop in attacking position - sometimes unpromoted is better for sacrifice attacks
❌ Silver in specific tactical situations - diagonal backward retreat can be useful
❌ Knight when you need the jumping ability

**Famous Saying**: "Promote for defense, stay unpromoted for attack!"

The decision to promote or not is one of Shogi's deep strategic choices. Wrong promotion can lose the game!

sections.title: Check, Checkmate & Game End
sections.content:
**Check** (王手, ōte):
When the King is under attack. You must:
1. Move the King to safety, OR
2. Block the attack with another piece, OR
3. Capture the attacking piece

**Checkmate** (詰み, tsumi):
King is in check with no legal moves to escape. Game over!

**Special Victory Conditions**:

**Uchifuzume** (打ち歩詰め) - ILLEGAL:
Checkmate delivered by a pawn drop is FORBIDDEN!
You can checkmate with a pawn move, but not a pawn drop.

**Sennichite** (千日手) - Repetition:
If the same position occurs 4 times, the game is replayed.
(Usually, whoever is checking loses the replay)

**Impasse** (持将棋, jishōgi) - RARE:
Both kings reach the opponent's promotion zone safely.
Points are counted:
• King = doesn't count
• Rook/Bishop = 5 points
• All other pieces = 1 point
Need 24+ points to draw (otherwise lose)

**Time Limit**:
Professional games have time controls (similar to chess).
Running out of time = loss

**Resignation** (投了, tōryō):
Most professional games end in resignation when a player sees inevitable defeat.
